All these wastes, along with intestinal output, are expelled through the cloaca, a versatile opening that also serves reproductive functions. Most fatty acids are non-essential, meaning the body can synthesize them as needed, usually from other fatty acids, and always by expending energy. Maintaining a balance of essential fatty acids—specifically omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids—appears important for health, although conclusive experimental evidence is still lacking. These "omega" long-chain polyunsaturated fatty acids are substrates for prostaglandins, a class of eicosanoids with various roles throughout the human body, functioning similarly to hormones. The omega-3 eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA), which can be synthesized in the human body from the omega-3 essential fatty acid alpha-linolenic acid (ALA) or ingested through marine food sources, serves as a precursor for series 3 prostaglandins, such as the weakly inflammatory PGE3. The omega-6 dihomo-gamma-linolenic acid (DGLA) acts as a precursor for series 1 prostaglandins.

General De Wimpffen, the stalwart commander of the French V Corps held in reserve, nurtured a fragile hope to unleash a tempest of combined infantry and cavalry against the Prussian XI Corps. But as the clock struck eleven, Prussian artillery thundered mercilessly, leaving French spirits battered and weary. Reinforcements swelled the Prussian ranks, and under the command of General Marguerite, French cavalry mounted three valiant but doomed charges upon the village of Floing, where the Prussian XI Corps lay entrenched. Marguerite, a beacon of bravery, fell in the first wave, his blood mingling with the dust of shattered hopes. The subsequent assaults, fierce yet futile, reaped only sorrow and slaughter. As twilight descended, the battlefield lay cloaked in despair; the French, their dreams of victory all but extinguished, stood on the precipice of surrender.
